results.title: The Baby of Macon
results.creator_credit: Peter Greenaway, Kees Kasander, La Sept, UGC Images and Channel Four
results.brief_description: Peter Greenaway’s film is visually sumptuous and confronting. Inspired by images of billboards featuring young children as icons, Greenaway’s film is set in the seventeenth century where child martyrs were similarly exploited. Rape, death, dismemberment occur when a miraculous child is the subject of a play that becomes too real. Stars Ralph Fiennes and Julia Ormond.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Greenaway, Kees Kasander, La Sept, UGC Images and Channel Four

results.title: The Baby Boomers' Picture Show
results.creator_credit: Stephen Ramsey, ABC-TV (Australia) and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Inspired by the book “Baby Boomers” by Helen Townsend, “The Baby Boomers’ Picture Show” re-creates the sensations, the thrills and the horrors of growing up in Australia in the 1950’s and 1960’s.

results.title: The Aztecs
results.brief_description: Describes the culture of the pre-Aztecs civilizations as evidenced in ruins, carvings, and murals of Tenochtitlan, Teotihuacan, Tula and Tenayuca. Emphasizes the important role of religion in the lives of Aztec people and re-enacts at Totihuacan, a religious ceremony as it might have been performed in 1500.

results.title: The Axedale project
results.brief_description: The construction of a bailey bridge and approaches, as a temporary crossing over the Campaspe River at Axedale to serve traffic while the existing bridge is taken out of service for provision of a new superstructure.

results.title: The Axe and the lamp
results.creator_credit: John Halas, British Film Institute and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: Peter Breugel’s painting “The Netherlandish Proverbs” illustrates over one hundred proverbs and allegorises a whole world of sin and folly as relevant today as in the 16th century.

results.title: The Awful truth
results.brief_description: One of the classic screwball comedies of the 1930s, “The Awful truth” was nominated for six Academy Awards, winning an Oscar for director Leo McCarey. This was the third time the story had been brought to the screen, this version particularly working because of the improvisation encouraged of the cast and crew. The actors’ state of bewilderment and the humour born from this is reinforced by the fact that much of their dialogue is ad-libbed. The story centres around New York couple the Warriners (Cary Grant and Irene Dunne), who both suspect the infidelities of the other. They agree to a trial divorce, but cannot agree on who will get custody of their pet dog Mr Smith. What follows is a battlefield of witty dialogue, slapstick, sophisticated New York versus Southern manners and sublime bickering, while the Warriners attempt to sabotage each other’s new romances and ultimately try to reunite.

results.title: The Awakening
results.creator_credit: Ron Tanner, Peter Griffiths, Lloyds Bank and Millbank Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Starting your own business”.
This is the second film in the series, Starting Your Own Business. The film continues the story of the three people who are self-employed, and it traces the first year in business for each of the characters. Again the problems and pitfalls involved in going it alone are identified and the audience can see the reasons why two of the businesses fail.

results.title: The Aviators of Hudson Strait
results.creator_credit: William Weintraub and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A look at early Canadian aviation, through film footage shot by the Royal Canadian Air Force and the recollections of retired Air Vice-Marshal Thomas A. Lawrence, leader of the 1927-28 aerial survey expedition to Ungava Bay and Hudson Strait. The formidable challenge of flying under Arctic conditions, the hazards faced and the emergencies solved, often with the help of Inuit, make an absorbing chapter of northern frontier history. Written by William Weintraub.

results.title: The Avengers. Vol. 01
results.brief_description: They were sauve, sophisticated and dangerous. Patrick Macnee and Diana Rigg, as Steed and Emma Peel delighted audiences worldwide in the sixties espionage thriller “The Avengers.” Two episodes are featured. “The Town of no return” shot in black and white in 1965, sees four agents disappear from a small remote village on the Norfolk coast and Steed and Peel are called upon to solve the case. “From Venus with love”, shot in colour in 1966, sees Steed and Peel in their own version of the “X-files” as astronomers are dying with their hair bleached white by an unknown killer.
